page.title: 11Local History of Silverdale
page.content: The skilfully constructed tall chimney of limestone which stands on the shoreline at Jenny Brown's point is the only remains of a copper smelting works established at the end of the 18th century. A deep channel enabled shipping to dock at the jetty, conveying machinery for the enterprise. Copper ore came from workings at Crag Foot, established in the days of the first Elizabeth. The nearby quarry provided stone for the breakwater, built to reclaim marshland. Mr A Shepherd of The Cove petitioned against the scheme, and later upheld via the House of Lords. The scheme was abandoned. During the last war the RAF used the area for bombing practice. An observer tower on the jetty was removed by the Air Ministry when it was vandalised.
